entry.et: Middle English, from Old English mūs; akin to Old High German mūs mouse, Latin mus, Greek mys mouse, muscle

def.dt: :any of numerous small rodents (as of the genus Mus) with pointed snout, rather small ears, elongated body, and slender tail
:a timid person
:a dark-colored swelling caused by a blow
:black eye
:a small mobile manual device that controls movement of the cursor and selection of functions on a computer display
:to hunt for mice
:to search or move stealthily or slowly
:bite gnaw
:to toy with roughly
:to search for carefully usually used with out
:a Eurasian hawkweed (Hieracium pilosella) introduced into North America that has soft hairy leaves and yellow flowers
:any of several plants other than mouse-ear that have soft hairy leaves
:any of several hairy chickweeds (genus Cerastium and especially C. fontanum)
:a thin flat pad (as of rubber) on which a computer mouse is used
:a person who spends a great deal of time using a computer
:behavior like that of a cat with a mouse: as
:the act of toying with or tormenting something before destroying it
:a contrived action involving constant pursuit, near captures, and repeated escapes played a game of cat and mouse with the police
:an evasive action
:any of various mice (genus Peromyscus) of North and Central America
:one (P. maniculatus) widely distributed in forests and grasslands of North America
:any of various mice and voles that inhabit fields
